Award.AwardTitle: NSF CDSE: Enabling Precise Constraints on Dark Energy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This goal of this proposal is to develop advanced techniques to calculate accurate and computationally efficient photometric redshift distance estimators, and to mitigate photometric uncertainties and systematics on clustering measures for galaxies found in large numbers in current and upcoming surveys. The computer codes will incorporate machine learning techniques with a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning algorithms. The methods developed will be applicable to the massive surveys to be undertaken by the future Large Synoptic Survey Telescope, which will, among other things, place precise constraints on Dark Energy.

Broader impacts of the work include training of a postdoc, a graduate student, and undergraduate students, and development of a course in Data Science to be available on line. All computational tools developed will be made available to the general astronomical community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major tasks of this funded effort was to improve the precision of constraints on cosmological parameters, especially dark energy equation of state parameters. Our approach involves increasing the size and purity of galaxy samples used for these measurements by developing state-of-the-art source classification and distance estimation techniques. In this manner, we can reduce stellar contamination (where stars in our galaxy are misclassified as distant galaxies), which adversely biases cosmological measurements, and we can more accurate slice galaxy samples by their distance from us, which allows the time-evolution of cosmological constraints to be computed. This grant funded one postdoctoral scholar, five graduate students (which led to two Ph.D. theses), and several undergraduate students.

Intellectual merit: The development of new random forest (Carrasco Kind, M. and Brunner, R. J. 2013, MNRAS, 432:1483–1501) and random atlas using self-organizing maps (Carrasco Kind, M. and Brunner, R. J. 2014, MNRAS, 438:3409–3421) methods, our Bayesian model combination framework for combining multi-dimensional regression estimates (Carrasco Kind, M. and Brunner, R. J. 2014, MNRAS, 442:3380–3399), the use of a sparse basis representation for compressing probability density functions (Carrasco Kind, M. and Brunner, R. J. 2014, MNRAS, 441:3550–3561), hybrid ensemble learning approaches (Kim, E., Brunner, R. and Carrasco Kind, M. 2015, MNRAS 453:507–521), deep convolutional neural networks (Kim, E. and Brunner, R. 2016, MNRAS 464:4463–4475), and semi-supervised generative adversarial networks (Kim, E. J. and Brunner, R. J. 2018, MNRAS, in review) for source identification and classification in massive imaging surveys. The application of machine learning techniques to accelerate the analysis of semi-analytical models (Kamdar, H. M., Turk, M. J., and Brunner, R. J. 2016, MNRAS, 455:642–658) and hydrodynamical cosmological simulations (Kamdar, H. M., Turk, M. J., and Brunner, R. J. 2016, MNRAS, 457:1162–1179).

Broader impacts: The publication of our methods and resultant software tools, the communication of these ideas and techniques to both the Dark Energy Survey and Large Synoptic Survey Telescope projects, the application of these techniques into new domains such as crop identification, and the development of new online Data Science courses.
